On RÃ©nyi Differential Privacy
in Statistics-Based Synthetic Data Generation

Takayuki Miura 11 â€ƒâ€ƒ Toshiki Shibahara 11 â€ƒâ€ƒ Masanobu Kii 11 â€ƒâ€ƒ Atsunori Ichikawa 11 â€ƒâ€ƒ Juko Yamamoto 11 â€ƒâ€ƒ Koji Chida 22
Abstract

Privacy protection with synthetic data generation often uses differentially private statistics and model parameters to quantitatively express theoretical security. However, these methods do not take into account privacy protection due to the randomness of data generation. In this paper, we theoretically evaluate RÃ©nyi differential privacy of the randomness in data generation of a synthetic data generation method that uses the mean vector and the covariance matrix of an original dataset. Specifically, for a fixed Î±>1ğ›¼1\alpha>1, we show the condition of Îµğœ€\varepsilon such that the synthetic data generation satisfies (Î±,Îµ)ğ›¼ğœ€(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RÃ©nyi differential privacy under a bounded neighboring condition and an unbounded neighboring condition, respectively. In particular, under the unbounded condition, when the size of the original dataset and synthetic dataset is 10 million, the mechanism satisfies (4,0.576)40.576(4,0.576)-RÃ©nyi differential privacy. We also show that when we translate it into the traditional (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy, the mechanism satisfies (4.00,10âˆ’10)4.00superscript1010(4.00,10^{-10})-differential privacy.

keywords:
synthetic data generation RÃ©nyi differential privacy privacy protection

1 Introduction

Personal data is expected to be utilized in various fields such as finance, healthcare, and medicine, but sharing personal data collected by one organization with another organization requires attention to individual privacy. Traditional anonymization techniques such as kğ‘˜k-anonymizationÂ [40] and randomized responseÂ [43] have struggled to find a good trade-off between utility and privacy for high-dimensional dataÂ [2]. In contrast, a synthetic data generation technique has emerged as a privacy protection method that preserves data utility even for high-dimensional data such as images and tabular data with multi-attributesÂ [6]. In synthetic data generation, values, which we call generative parameters, are extracted from the original raw dataset, and then synthetic data are generated randomly as shown in Fig.Â 1(a). The synthetic data are the same format as the original data and statistically similar to them. Typical generative parameters are statistics of original data and trained parameters of deep neural networksÂ [38, 26, 5, 15, 45, 46, 30, 17, 44, 24, 36]. After the synthetic data are generated, they are shared with other organizations, but the generative parameters are typically discarded without being disclosed.

To guarantee privacy protection theoretically, differential privacyÂ [11] is used as a standard framework. By adding randomness in generative parameter calculation, the generative parameters become differentially privateÂ [29, 45, 1]. The post-processing property of differential privacy guarantees that synthetic data generated with differentially private generative parameters also satisfy differential privacy as shown in Fig.Â 1(b). Although the synthetic data generated with non-differentially private generative parameters have high utility, those with differentially private parameters are known to have lower utilityÂ [41].

We address this problem by evaluating differential privacy of randomness in data generation when using non-differentially private generative parameters. As mentioned above, in the context of anonymization, the generative parameters are often discarded without disclosing them to the public. When the output is not generative parameters but only synthetic data, we can consider that it has already been protected by the randomness even if the generative parameters are not protected with differential privacy as shown in Fig.Â 1(a). If privacy protection in data generation is quantitatively evaluated, theoretically guaranteed synthetic data can be obtained without degrading the utility. Moreover, by incorporating this result into traditional methods, we expect to keep the same level of security with smaller additional randomness; that is, we can obtain higher utility synthetic data.

In this paper, we regard a record as a dğ‘‘d-dimensional vector and focus on a synthetic data generation mechanism with the mean vector and the covariance matrix of the original dataset shown in Fig.Â 2. We theoretically evaluate RÃ©nyi differential privacyÂ [34], which is a relaxed concept of differential privacy, by randomness in generation for the method. We explicitly derive the condition of Îµğœ€\varepsilon such that the synthetic data generation mechanism satisfies (Î±,Îµ)ğ›¼ğœ€(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RÃ©nyi differential privacy for a fixed Î±>1ğ›¼1\alpha>1 under the unbounded neighboring condition (TheoremÂ 3.1) and the bounded neighboring condition (CorollaryÂ 3.2). Furthermore, we conduct a numerical evaluation with reference to the Adult datasetÂ [9] and compute Îµğœ€\varepsilon concretely. We demonstrate that when the size of original dataset is 10 million and the mechanism outputs data the same size as the input dataset, it satisfies (4,0.576)40.576(4,0.576)-RÃ©nyi differential privacy under the unbounded condition and (4,2.307)42.307(4,2.307)-RÃ©nyi differential privacy under the bounded condition (TableÂ 1). If they are translated into the traditional (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy, the mechanism satisfies (4.00,10âˆ’10)4.00superscript1010(4.00,10^{-10}) and (7.88,10âˆ’10)7.88superscript1010(7.88,10^{-10}) differential privacy under the unbounded and bounded condition, respectively (TableÂ 2). These values are mostly similar to ones used by AppleÂ [4] and US CensusÂ [42].

2.1 Notations

2.2 Differential Privacy

In this subsection, we introduce (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacy and (Î±,Îµ)ğ›¼ğœ€(\alpha,\varepsilon)-RÃ©nyi differential privacy. First, we define neighboring datasets.

Definition 2.1 (Neighboring datasets)

Datasets D,Dâ€²âˆˆğ’Ÿğ·superscriptğ·â€²ğ’ŸD,D^{\prime}\in\mathcal{D} are neighboring datasets if Dğ·D and Dâ€²superscriptğ·â€²D^{\prime} are different only in one record. When datasets have a fixed size nğ‘›n, we call the neighboring condition a bounded conditionÂ [23]. In this case, neighboring means changing the value of exactly one record. When datasets have no such restriction, we call the neighboring condition an unbounded conditionÂ [23]. In this case, neighboring means either adding or removing one record.111This difference is important for the sensitivity of queries. For example, the sensitivity of the mean value query under the bounded condition is twice as large as that under the unbounded condition.

(Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-differential privacyÂ [11] is defined as follows.

Definition 2.2 (differential privacyÂ [11])

In particular, â„³â„³\mathcal{M} satisfies Îµğœ€\varepsilon-DP if it satisfies (Îµ,0)ğœ€0(\varepsilon,0)-DP.

For a dğ‘‘d-dimensional symmetric matrix Ağ´A, the following two conditions are equivalent:

6 Related Work

In this section, we describe the related work and mention the difference from our result.

6.1 Differentially Private Synthetic Data Generation

In synthetic data generation, the post-processing property of differential privacy guarantees that synthetic data generated from differentially private generative parameters also satisfy differential privacy as shown in Fig.Â 1(b). Methods to generage differentially private synthetic data for tabular data are classified to two types.

The first type is also called a â€œselect-measure-generateâ€ schemeÂ [29]. Statistics and (conditional) probability distributions are used as the generative parameters. Typical statistics are mean vectors and covariance matrices of original datasets. In particular, synthetic data generation with copulas has been researched activelyÂ [38, 26, 5, 15]. To learn conditional distributions, graphical models such as Bayesian networks have been applied to synthetic data generationÂ [45, 46, 30, 31].

In the second type, generative models with deep neural networks are used to generate synthetic data. The model parameters trained with the original data are regarded as the generative parameters. By training deep neural networks with differentially private stochastic gradient descent (DP-SGD)Â [1], we obtain differentially private model parameters. Methods based on generative adversarial networks (GAN) such as CTGANÂ [44], DPCTGANÂ [13], CTAB-GANÂ [47], and CTAB-GAN+Â [48], are widely used. A method based on diffusion model such as TabDDPMÂ [25] has also attracted attention recently.

In both types of approaches, generative parameters are computed by various differentially private mechanismsÂ [1, 32] (Fig.Â 1(b)). In contrast, we evaluate differential privacy of randomness in data generation when using non-differentially private generative parameters.

6.2 Privacy Attacks against Synthetic Data Generation

Many methods empirically evaluate the privacy protection of synthetic data generations from attack success rates of membership inference attacksÂ [37] and attribute inference attacksÂ [14]. Most of them assume that an adversary has access to the target trained model such as GANÂ [8, 19, 20] and diffusion modelsÂ [7, 21, 10, 28].

On the other hands, there are several methods where an adversary only has access to output synthetic data. Stadler et al.Â [39] discussed membership inference attacks and attribute inference attacks for tabular data in such setting, and Oprisanu et al.Â [35] applied such attacks to genomic data. Annamalai et al.Â [3] conducted attribute inference with linear reconstruction in this setting.

Although these studies and ours share a common perspective in that they focus on the privacy protection of generated synthetic data alone, these studies differ from ours in that they experimentally evaluate synthetic data generation from an attack perspective. In contrast, our perspective is to prove RÃ©nyi differential privacy theoretically.

6.3 Differential Privacy of Randomness in Synthetic Data Generation

To the best of our knowledge, only Lin et al.Â [27] have evaluated the privacy protection by the randomness in outputs of synthetic data generations. They theoretically evaluated probabilistic differential privacyÂ [33] of GAN-sampled data. However, the concretely evaluated bound is hard to compute since it needs a GANâ€™s generalization error. In addition, they assume that training datasets are far larger than the number of model parameters. Thus, their main contribution is to give the theoretical bound, but we cannot compute the bound as a concrete numerical value.

In contrast, although we focus on only a simple synthetic data generation, we give the concretely computable bound.

7 Conclusion

In this paper, we evaluated the privacy protection due to the randomness of synthetic data generation without adding intentional randomness. We proved RÃ©nyi differential privacy of a synthetic data generation with a mean vector and covariance matrix (TheoremÂ 3.1, CorollaryÂ 3.2). We also conducted numerical evaluations using the Adult dataset as a model case. Concretely, we demonstrated that the mechanism â„³Gnsuperscriptsubscriptâ„³ğºğ‘›\mathcal{M}_{G}^{n} satisfies (4,0.576)40.576(4,0.576)-RDP under the unbounded condition and (4,2.307)42.307(4,2.307)-RDP under the bounded condition (TableÂ 1). If they are translated into (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP, â„³Gnsuperscriptsubscriptâ„³ğºğ‘›\mathcal{M}_{G}^{n} satisfies (Îµ,Î´)ğœ€ğ›¿(\varepsilon,\delta)-DP for a practical Îµğœ€\varepsilon (TableÂ 2). In future work, we will apply our evaluation method to more advanced synthetic data generation algorithms.
